review.title: The Influence of Context on Dialogue Act Recognition
review.abstract: This article presents a deep analysis of the influence of context information on dialogue act recognition. We performed experiments on the annotated subsets of three different corpora: the widely explored Switchboard Dialog Act Corpus, as well as the unexplored LEGO and Cambridge Restaurant corpora.

sections.heading: 3. Corpora
sections.text: ISO 24617-2 is the current and only existing standard for the annotation of dialogue files. However, since it is a newer standard, the amount of data commented on after it is small, leaving room for questions about the soundness of the results obtained through experiments with it. Therefore, we also conducted experiments on the large and widely researched cabinet body.

sections.heading: 3.1 Switchboard
sections.text: It was a corpus of about 2400 telephone conversations among 543 American English speakers (302 male and 241 female), each pair of speakers was automatically assigned to a topic of discussion, from 70 different ones. However, speaker pairings and subject attributions were restricted so that no two speakers spoke to each other more than once and no one talked about a particular topic. Speech from the two subjects was recorded into separate channels, using an 8 kHz sampling rate.A subset of 1155 manually transcribed conversations (commented with disfluence, waiver, and interruption information), each containing 223606 segments, was set using the SWBD-DAMSL marker (Jurafsky, Shriberg, and Biasca 1997). sections.heading: 4.2 Classification
sections.text: As explained in Section 2, several approaches to detecting dialogue files, such as those used by Stolcke et al. (2000) on the Conciliation Committee, attempt to predict the best dialogue sequence for a particular conversation. However, our work focuses on detecting dialogue files during a conversation between a dialogue system and its interlocutor. In this scenario, such approaches are not useful as the system, although it may have expectations, cannot be certain how the conversation will develop. Therefore, we have opted for an approach based on prior and current information. As we want to assess the impact of context information on dialogue character recognition, we must be able to limit the amount of information provided. Instead of a sequential approach, such as HMMs or CRFs, we have opted for an approach based on SVMs that are already based on the state of the art approach used for this task (Gambäck, Olsson and Täckström 2011).

sections.heading: 4.3 Evaluation
sections.text: We use accuracy, i.e. the ratio between the number of correct predictions and the total number of predictions, as a benchmark of performance, as it has consistently been chosen as the benchmark for evaluating performance in the detection of dialog files. As there are no fully disclosed corpora training and test partitions, a rigorous comparative study is not possible. Therefore, we opted for 10-fold cross validation as a method of evaluation. However, in order to make comparisons with some of the related work, other fold numbers were also used. Nevertheless, the presented results, unless otherwise stated, were obtained by 10-fold cross validation. In order to evaluate the statistical significance of the differences between the multiple results obtained on the same data, we defined a significance level of 5% and performed the Wilcoxon Signed Rank Test (Wilcoxon 1945). Thus, if we say that a difference is significant / insignificant, it means that the p value of the test was below 5%.

metadata.abstractText: This article presents an analysis of the influence of context information on dialog act recognition. We performed experiments on the widely explored Switchboard corpus, as well as on data annotated according to the recent ISO 24617-2 standard. The latter was obtained from the Tilburg DialogBank and through the mapping of the annotations of a subset of the Let’s Go corpus. We used a classification approach based on SVMs, which had proved successful in previous work and allowed us to limit the amount of context information provided. This way, we were able to observe the influence patterns as the amount of context information increased. Our base features consisted of n-grams, punctuation, and wh-words. Context information was obtained from one to five preceding segments and provided either as n-grams or dialog act classifications, with the latter typically leading to better results and more stable influence patterns. In addition to the conclusions about the importance and influence of context information, our experiments on the Switchboard corpus also led to results that advanced the state-of-the-art on the dialog act recognition task on that corpus. Furthermore, the results obtained on data annotated according to the ISO 24617-2 standard define a baseline for future work and contribute for the standardization of experiments in the area.
